hi. Et ipse destruit me, non tamen destruit naturam meam. e41-17Et ipse est Satur-
nus, qui separat omnia mea membra: Postea vado ad matrem meam, quæae con-
gregat omnia membra divisa & separata: e41-18Ego sum illuminans omnia
mea, & facio lumen apparere patenter in itinere de patre meo Saturno, & et-
iam de matre mea quæae mihi inimicatur. e41-19Hactenus dicta adeò clara sunt,
ut vel mediocriter in lectione authorum versato tenebras à mentis
oculis discutiant, & lucem solarem patefaciant, quæae in concordan-
tiis adductis rerum & personarum abundè perspicitur. e41-20Nam
quæae vera sunt, etiamsi sub velo allegoriæae tecta, miro inter se suffra-
gio consentiunt, quæae falsa, secum cumq́ue aliis pugnant,& in diver-
sa abeunt.

html.head: s Atalanta Fugiens (Maier Edition. transcription) Facsimile Copy. Emblem

div.h1:
Dem / der in Chymicis versiret, sen di Natur / Bernunfft /
Erfahrenheit und Lefen / wie ein Führer / Stab /
Brijllen und Lampen.

div.span: Dein Führerin di Natur sen / welch'r du must folgen von meiten /
Williglich / anderst du frist / wo sie dich nicht thut lenten /
Die Bernunffe sen dein Stab / und es muß stärken die Erfahrnheit
Dein Gesicht / daß du könnst sehen / was gelegt ist weit und breit /
Daß Lesen sen wie ein Lamp im finstern leuchtend hell und klar /
Dadurch du mögst verhüten der Sachn und Wörter Gefahr.

div.h1:
In Chymicis versanti Natura, Ratio, Experientia & lectio,ob
sint Dux, scipio, perspicilia & lampas.

div.span: Dux Natura tibi, túque arte pedissequus illi
Esto lubens, erras, ni comes ipsa viæae est.
Det ratio scipionis opem, Experientia firmet
Lumina, quò possit cernere posta procul.
Lectio sit lampas tenebris dilucida, rerum
Verborúmque strues providus ut caveas.

div.div:
e42-01 Casus, qui peregrinantibus accidere possunt, innumeri sunt,
præaesertim si pedibus noctu per loca lubrica & periculosa iter fa-
cere instituant: ad quod quatuor tanquam summè necessaria re-
quiruntur, ne de viatico & robusto corpore quiquam dicamus:
e42-02 Primò locorum, per quæae eundum erit, non ignarus comes aut dux:
Si enim ignarus ignarum duxerit, idem iis quod cæaecis contingit, ut
si non in foveam, tamen in errores & ambages ambo præaecipitentur:
e42-03 Secundò, bacillus vel scipio, quo viæae lubricitas, ne cui damnosa sit,
præaecavetur: e42-04 Tertiò, oculi sani; cæaecis enim aut lippis ejusmodi iti-
nera sunt periculosissima: e42-05 Quartò lampas sive fax incensa; ut discri-
mina viarum dignosci possint. e42-06 Eodem modo si quis difficilimo se
committat itineri, ut Medicinam Philosophicam indaget, præaeter
sumptus & corporis robur, quaterna desiderabit ante dictis paral-
lela & correspondẽtiacorrespondentia ex æaequo, videlicet Naturam, Rationem, Ex-
perientiam & Lectionem: quorum si unum aut alternum defuerit, re-
liqua parùm aut nihil juvabunt: e42-07 Hisce enim, tanquam quatuor rotis
currus Philosophicus incedit, cui ex rotis una deesse nequit, si super-
sit, nil prodest. e42-08 Natura præaesupponit corpora naturalia, & spiritus,
tanquam subjecta primo à natura ministrata, in quæae ars postea agat
id præaeparando, purificando & habile reddendo, ut de eo id fieri pos-
sit, quod ars pro fine promittit: e42-09 Sic figulus sumit aquam & terram,
vitrarius cineres & arenam, faber ferrum, æaes stannum, plumbum,
argentum vel aurum, coriarius pelles crudas & sic alii alia:
Ita quoque chymiæae artifex ad sua materialia respicit: e42-10 Illis sua sunt
notissima vel primo die, huic per multos annos, cùm incipit, ple-
rumque ignota manent, ne dicam per totam vitam. e42-11 Natura quidẽquidem
digitum intendit in materias, sed multa sunt, quæae impressionem na-
turæae obscurent, ut agnosci nequeat. e42-12 Prima itaque intentio est, na-
turam intimè contemplari quomodo procedat in suis operationi-
bus eo fine, ut subjecta Chymiæae naturalia absque defectu aut super-
fluitate haberi queant: Unde natura sit dux & comes tanti itineris,
cujus vestigia sequenda sunt. e42-13 Secundò Ratio sit instar scipionis;
qui firmet gressus & pedes stabiliat, ne vacillent; Absq;Absque ratiocinatio-

ne enim quis ad lapsum in errores erit proclivis, Unde dicunt Philo-
sophi; Quicquid audis, ratiocinare, num ita esse possit, necne. e42-14 Ad im-
possibilia enim credenda vel peragenda nemo impellitur, nisi ipse
debilis memoriæae, obtusi ingenii & fatuæae imaginationis, ut sibi im-
ponat falsa pro veris accipiendo & vera pro falsis renuendo: e42-15 Ajunt
quoque se non curare de verbis, quicquid dicatur, sed saltem de re-
bus, quid intelligatur; Et verba esse propter res & non res propter
verba. e42-16 Exempli gratia, dicat quis, tincturâ Philosophicâ vitrum fie-
ri malleabile. Quid ni hoc credidero, si modò ratio dictet? e42-17 Tertiò
Experientia dabit perspicilia, quibus remota videri possint; Hæaec
sunt instrumenta optica imbecillitatem oculorum humanorum ju-
vantia & corrigentia, arte inventa & facta. e42-18 His persimilia sunt Ex-
perimenta circa mineralem materiam cujusque generis tentata,
visa vel verè audita; quæae quò plura fuerint in memoria, eò plura ra-
tiocinatio inde sumet & inter & cum aliis comparabit, ut animad-
vertat, quid sit verum, quid non. e42-19 Quartò Lectio quasi lampada per-
spicuam in intellectu incendat, sine qua erunt ubique tenebræae &
densæae nubes. e42-20 Debet autem lectio bonorum authorum sæaepè iterari;
aliàs nihil proderit. e42-21 Hinc Bacasser in turba: Qui ergo inquit, longa-
nimis erit, libentérque patientiâ fruitur, in tramite justo hujus artis meabit
qui verò citius se putat ex libris nostris fructum capere posse fallitur satiusque
fuerat, non inspicere quidem, quàm unquam contigisse: Et quæae ibidem se-
quuntur.

html.head: s Atalanta Fugiens (Maier Edition. transcription) Facsimile Copy. Emblem

div.h3: FUGA XLIII. in 5. seu 12. infrà. Contrapunctum.
div.h1:
Hörzu gen Geijer so reden kan / der fälschlich
dich nicht sezet an.

div.span: Auff der Spizen hoch deß Bergs der Geijer thut sizende laut schreijn
Ohn unterlaß: Ich bin der weisse und schwarze allein /
Der Citron Farb und roht: Ich lieg nicht; der selb is auch der Rab
So fleugt / ob wol ihm seijn die Flugel geschnidten ab /
In finster Nacht / auch wenn di Sonn erhoben am Mittag steht /
Dann dieser / oder der ist / darauß die ganze Kunst geht.

div.h1: Audi loquacem vulturem, qui neutiquam te decipit.

div.span: Montis in excelso consistit vertice vultur
Assiduè clamans; Albus ego atque niger,
Citrinus, rubeúsque feror nil mentior: idem est
Corvus, qui pennis absque volare solet
Nocte tenebrosâ, mediâque in luce diei,
Namque artis caput est ille vel iste tuæae.

div.div:
e43-01Loquaces seu vocis humanæae æaemulas volucres, videlicet Psitta-
cos, corvos, monedulas, & picas quotidiè passim audimus. e43-02Sic
Plinius suo tempore, quo historiam edidit, AgrippinãAgrippinam Claudii Cęsa-
risCaesa-
ris uxorem habuisse turdum, semones hominum imitantem scribit.
e43-03Habuerunt & Cæaesares juvenes sturnum & luscinias Græaeco latinó-
que sermoni assuefactas, & assiduè nova loquentes longo etiam ver-
borum filo. e43-04Cumq́ue ejusmodi nõnon raræae occurrant aves, minùs admi-
ratione dignæae nunc censentur, siquidem usus & assuefactio omnes
volucres latiori lingua præaeditas hoc modo vocales & garrulas red-
dere possit. e43-05Verùm vultur ille, cujus Philosophi mentionem faciunt,
voces, si quas edit, non ex usu didicit, sed eas natura ipsius tacitè ex-
primit. e43-06Philosophi verò dicunt, quod assiduè clamet, altáque voce
pronunciet, quis sit & qualis, in quo magnos imitatur principes, qui
titulos suos & hæaereditates semper in initio suarum intimationum
innotescere volunt, non superbiæae alicujus notâ, sed aliorum causa,
ut & ipsi sciant, quibus principatibus dominentur, aut jus hæaeredita-
rium præaetendant. e43-07Sic multum interest, ut agnoscatur, quibus colo-
ribus, tanquam armorum & titulorum insignibus, Philosophica a-
vis gaudeat, & cæaeteras antecellat. e43-08Ego, inquit, ut Rosarius habet ex
Hermete, sum nigrum albi, & Citrinus rubei, & certè veridicus sum
& non mentiens. e43-09Nigrum se adfirmat, album, citrinum & rubeum,
& talis reverà est, etsi enim tres ultimos colores actu nondum possi-
deat, tamen hæaereditatum eorum expectat. e43-10Hinc Rosinus in lib.libro di-
vinarum interpretationum; Recipe, inquit, lapidem, qui est niger,
albus, rubeus, citrinus, avis mirabilis, qui nigredine noctis, & diei
claritate sine alis volat. e43-11Ex amaritudine namque in suo gutture exi-
stente, coloratio accipitur, à suo verò cruore mera aqua accipitur,
sicut dixit Alexander. Recipe lapidem quatuor colorum fili. e43-12Colo-
res hosce omnes, qui sunt principales, successio ordine adesse lapidi,
ad nauseam Philosophorum libri dictitant. e43-13Cur verò Vultur appel-
letur Philosophicum subjectum, non abs re erit. Ex vulturibus nigri
præaevalent, rapaces sunt, sed tardè volant, propter corporis molem.
e43-14Ajunt hanc avem concipere sine masculorum semine, & sine con-

junctione generare, natósque ex iis in multam æaetatem procedere
ad annum usque centesimum. Nidificant isn altis rupibus, nidos ne-
mo attigi. e43-15Fœoetus ferè cernuntur bini: Auxilio sunt contra ser-
pentes. Euro gravidæae fiunt. e43-16Cùm cœoeperunt ova edere, aliquid adfe-
runt ex Indico tractu, quod est tanquam nux, intùs habens, quod
moveatur, sonḿquesonumque subinde reddat, quod ubi sibi apposuerunt,
multos fœoetus producunt, sed unus tantum remanet, qui Immusu-
lus vocatur. e43-17Hermodorus Fonticus apud Cœoelium testis est, vultu-
res esse omnium animalium innocentissimos, quia nihil prorsus at-
tingant eorum, quæae ferant homines, plantent, alant. Animantium
præaeterea nullam interimant. e43-18Volucribus quoque vel mortuis abs-
tineant, quodam cognationis intellectu: Hinc in auguriis præaestan-
tissimi habebantur, ut indicant Urbis Romæae primordia. e43-19Has vultu-
rum proprietates ferè omnes cùm Philosophicus ales exprimat,
hinc non immeritò vultur ab Hermete aliísque appellatur, qui &
tardus in volatu & niger colore est; Concipit ex sese: e43-20Sic enim Rosa-
rius circa finem; Et ipse est draco, qui maritat seipsum & impræaegnat
seipsum & parit in die suo, etcetcaetera. e43-21Et Rosinus ad sarratant: Et ipsum est ser-
pens seipsum luxurians, seipsum impræaegnans & in die una parturiens, etcetcaetera.
e43-22Diutissimè vivit & superest, seq́ue multiplicat. Quod enim Virgilius
de Phœoenice ave scribit, huic æaequè (quia eadem est) convenit:
Alipedem cervum corvus ter vincit, at illum
Multiplicat novies Phœoenix reparabilis ales:
e43-23Hujus nidos attingere valdè difficilè est: Cum serpente Mercuriali pugnat,
eúmq;eumque vincit, hoc est, Sol cum luna. e43-24Ex vento concipitur, & in ventre ejus por-
tatur, & in aëre nascitur. ÆAetites lapis lapillum habẽshabens intra se sonantem, à multis
totiũtotium dicitur. e43-25Unus saltem immusulus in nido Philos.Philosophico invenitur. Innocentissima
quoq;quoque avis est Philos.Philosophica quia nulli nocet, omnibus scientibus prodest, & in augu-
riis præaestantissima. e43-26At cur in monte nidificat, & sedens ita clamat? Respondet
Rosinus ex Rasi, qui inquit: Contemplare altissima montana, quæae sunt à dextris & à
sinistris, ac ascende illuc: Ibi lapis noster invenitur, & in alto monte, qui fert omne genus pi-
gmentorum, & spiritus vel species, ibi similiter est: e43-27Morienus: Conscendite alta montana,
arboribus consita quia ibi lapis noster invenitur & absconditus est: Et Hermes: Recipite lapi-
dem benedictum, comminuite & lavate lapidem rubeum, de quo extrahitur, qui invenitur
in montibus & maximè aliquando in cloacis veteribus.

html.head: s Atalanta Fugiens (Maier Edition. transcription) Facsimile Copy. Emblem

div.h3: FUGA XLIV. in 5. seu 12. suprà. Basi sola proportione existente.
div.h1:
Durch Betrug Typhon Osirim tödtet / und seine Glieder
zerstrewet / welche widerumb zusammen bringt die Isis,
so weit berümbt.

div.span: Syrien Adonim hat / Dionysum Griechenland eben /
Egypten Osirim, so seijnd die Sonn den Weisen geben /
Die Isis ist die Schwester / auch Mutter und Osiridis Weib /
Welchs Glieder der Typhon theilt / sie wider fügt in ein Leib /
Ihm aber gebrach das Glied deß Manns / im Wasser verlohren /
Dann der Schwebel vergeht / so den Schwebel gebohren.

div.h1:
Dolo Typhon Osyridem trucidat, artúsque illius
Hinc inde dissipat, sed hos collegit Isis inclyta.

div.span: Syria Adonidem habet, Dionysum Græaecia, Osirim
ÆAegyptus, qui sunt nil nisi Sol Sophiæae:
Isis adest soror, & conjunx ac mater Osiris,
Cujus membra Typhon dissecat, illa ligat.
Defluit at pudibunda mari pars, sparsa per undas,
Sulphur enim, Sulphur quod generavit, abest.

div.div:
e44-01Osyridis allegoriam alibi, nempe in 1. lib.libro Hieroglyph.Hieroglyphicorum ad suam
veram originem, quæae Chymica est, reduximus & plenariè ex-
plicavimus. Quocirca hic eadem repetere (quamvis eadem de iisdẽiisdem
dici debeãtdebeant) supervacaneum arbitramur. e44-02At nihilominùs discursum
hi instituemus parallelum, ɋqui intra carceres Antiquæae Chymiæae (quęquae
tota poëtis decantata & figurata est) semper versabitur & manebit.
e44-03Osyridem tu mihi Deum, aut regem ÆAegytpium persuadebis? Non
Non credam, etiamsi persuaseris, ut credam: Longè aliter enim canes,
longè aliter (ut est in proverbio) sues olent: Deum planè nego, & tu
mihi assentiêris, nisi sis Ethnicus aut distortæae à recta ratione opinio-
nis. e44-04Regem nec fuisse, demonstratur ex circumstantiis omnib.omnibus quæae
alibi considerantur: Sol est, sed Philos.Philosophicus cujus nomen cùm illi passim
attributum legatur, vulgares, qui nullum alium nisi mundanum il-
lud lumen noverunt, pro eo interpretati sunt. e44-05A sole mundi sol Phi-
losophorum denominantionem habet, quia proprietates naturæae ab
illo sole cœoelesti descendentes, aut ei convenientes, continet. e44-06Sol ita-
que Osyris est, Dionysus, Bacchus, Jupiter, Mars, Adonis, Oedypus,
Perseus, Achilles, Triptolemus, Pelops, Hippomenes, Pollux. e44-07Luna
verò Isis, Juno, Venus, mater Oedypi, Danaë, Deidamia, Atalanta,
Helena: Item Latona, Semele, Europa, Leda, Antiope, Thalia. e44-08Atq;Atque
hæae sunt compositi partes, quod ante operationem lapis dicitur, &
nomine omnis metalli, Magnesia: post operationem, Orcus, Pyr-
rus, Apollo, ÆAesculapius. e44-09Adjuncta sunt, Typhon, Python, Aper:
Artifex Hercules, Ulysses, Jason, Theseus, Pyrithous: Labores &
pericula innumera, quæae ab his artificibus exantlata fuere. e44-10Videan-
tur Herculis labores, Ulyssis errores, Jasonis pericula, Thesei cona-
tus & Pyrithoi remoræae. e44-11Magnum hoc est materiæae & doctrinæae volu-
men, per quod Vulcanus, Mercurius & Saturnus omnibus paginis
currunt & recurrunt, hic ut pater omnium & causa, sine qua non, ille,
ut materia & forma, iste, ut efficiens. e44-12Sol ducit sororem lunam in u-
xorem. Jupiter Junonem, ut Saturnus Rheam, & Osyris Isidem:
Dionysus ex matre Semele combusta fulmine Jovis eripitur imma-
turandus in femore Jovis patris, ÆAesculapius ex Coronide matre:

e44-13Dionysus adultus novam vini potionem monstrat hominibus usq;usque
in Indiam expeditionem suscipiens; Osiris & Triptolemus, frugum
seminationem & usum, ÆAesculapius, medicinæae administrationem:
Dionysus Græaecis sic dictus, Romanis Bacchus est, ÆAegtypiis Osiris,
Syriis Adonis. e44-14Oedypus patrem occîdit, & matrem duxit; Perseus
avum interemit, Typhon fratrem Osirim, aper Adonim, Ceres
nutrix Triptolemi patrem ejus Eleusium; Hippomenes pomo au-
reo Atalantam vicit, Tantalus pater Pelopis Hippodamiam curruli
certamine obtinuit. e44-15Osiris in partes dissectus & ab Iside matre, soro-
re & conjuge iterùm conjunctus fuit. Pelops puer coctus & bullitus
humero à Cerere depasto vitæae restitutus, addito humero eburneo:
e44-16Achilles & Triptolemus sub carbonibus noctu positi, & interdiu la-
cte nutriti sunt, hic à Cerere nutrice, ille à Thetide matre: Achilles &
Helena Trojani belli causæae fuerunt, hæaec ut impulsiva, ille ut effi-
ciens; Helena nata ex ovo est, & in Pelei & Thetidis nuptiis, ex quib.quibus
Achilles natus, pomum Eridos, prima causa raptus Helenæae, proje-
ctum fuit. e44-17Pollux adfuit Argonautis, qui quinquaginta ferè annis
ante bellem Trojanum inceptum vixisse præaesupponuntur (si vixe-
rint) & Helena cum Polluce ex uno ovo prodiit; e44-18Fuit itaque anus
Helena, cùm raperetur à Paride: Achilli in Elysiis campis Medea
nupsit, tum anus edentula: nisi fortè sibi juventem restituit, ut ÆAe-
soni, Jasonis patri, & Ceres Pelopi, unde bis pubescens appellatur:
e44-19Perseus alatum equum accepit à Pallade, eiq́ue caput Medusæae in
remunerationem attulit, cui Mercurius harpen, & alii Dii alia arma
ministrârunt, Triptolemus à Cerere currum cum draconibus alatis:
e44-20Ex Jovis cerebro Pallade nata Rhodi pluit aurum, ut & Sole concũ-
benteconcum-
bente cum Venere; Et Jupiter, ut aurum compressit Danaen, ut
Cygnus Ledam, ut cuculus sororem Junonem; ut Taurus Euro-
pam, ut Satyrus Antiopen, & sic concordantia est in omnibus.

html.head: s Atalanta Fugiens (Maier Edition. transcription) Facsimile Copy. Emblem

div.h3: FUGA XLV. in 3. suprà. vertendo Bas.sum et incip.e ab initio in clave d.
div.h1:
Die Sonn und ihr Schatten vollnbringen
das Werck.

div.span: Die SoñSonn deß Him̃elsHimmels klares Liecht kan nicht dicke Leiber durchgehn /
Drumb bleibt ein Schatten an den Orten / so sie nicht kan sehn /
Ob wol derselbige ist sehr gering uner den Dingen allen /
Jedoch thut er nüzlich der Astronomnis gefallen /
Aber mehr Geschenck geben hat den Weisen die Sonne und ihr Schatt /
Dann sie die gülden Kunst vollenführen mit der That.

div.h1: Sol & ejus umbra perficiunt opus.

div.span: Sol, fax clara poli, non corpora densa penétrat,
Hinc illi adversis partibus umbra manet:
Vilior hæaec rebus quamvis est omnibus, usu
Attamen Astronomis commoda multa tulit:
Plura Sophis sed dona dedit Sol, ejus & umbra,
Auriferæae quoniam perficit artis opus.

div.div:
e45-01Quemadmodum in Palatio rotundo seu formæae sphæaericæae, uno
loco ignis incensus illustrat circum circa omnes parietes supe-
riores & inferiores partes, exceptis iis ubi mẽsamensa vel tabula in medio
consistens suo objectu impediat & umbram tenebrosam admittat,
ita & Sol in magno illo cœoeli palatio sive Theatro cœoelato constitutus
omnem cœoeli concavitatem, contenta in eâ diaphana & lucis rece-
ptiva corpora, hoc est, stellas quascunque, errantes & fixas, radiis suis
illuminat, nisi ubi Terræae intermediæae densitas prohibeat: e45-02Ibi enim
umbra nigra & tenebrosa, quæae nox dicitur, tam diu permanet, do-
nec solis præaesentiâ fugetur & lux ejus vice fundatur & conspiciatur.
e45-03Est itaque umbra & nox solaris lucis privatio seu absentia, dies ecõ-
traecon-
tra irradiatio & circumfusio. e45-04Umbra est, quæae solis aspectum tolera-
re nequit, idcirco fugiens & se abscondens nunc ab hac, nunc ab illa
parte terræae, pro ut sol est ex opposito. e45-05Nunquam Sol & umbra se in-
vicem viderun, quamvis in momento quovis, si natura admitteret,
possent; sed sol ut inimicam sibi audiens semper illi insistit fugienti,
nec unquam defessam capere potest, ut pulchrè Buchananus in li-
bro sphæaerico cecinit. e45-06Ad imitationem & exemplum magni illius so-
lis, ejúsque umbræae, Philosophi observârunt & suo soli adesse umbrãumbram
nigram, nebulosam & fugacem: Hinc Hermes, Fili, inquit, extrahe
à radio suam umbram, hoc est, vide ut solem tuum circum ducas per
primum mobile, cui Vulcanus præaeficitur, ut & illa Terræae tDophiduæae pars,
quæae nunc umbrosâ nocte tegitur, clarâ fruatur luce solari: e45-07Nisi e-
nim per motum primum totum Firmamentum cœoeli cum omnibus
contentis singulis diebus naturalibus, hoc est, viginti quatuor horis
semel circumduceretur, sed saltem motu suo proprio, secundo &
annuo dicto Sol moveretur, qui infra nos sunt Antipodes, ferè seme-
stri temporis spacio noctem habere & nos diem unum contingeret,
& post vice versa illos diem & nos noctem: e45-08ut sic totus annus ex una
nocte & die constaret, veluti nunc sub utroque polo hæae vices expe-
rimento & ratione verissimæae comprobantur. e45-09At providentiæae Divi-
næae longè aliter visum fuit, quæae ideò duplices motus ordinavit pla-
netarum, primum & secundum, & sic annum in multos dies distri-

buit: e45-10Umbra autem illa & sol diem & noctem faciunt simul, quod
sol per se solus non posset, cujus est illuminare omnia opposita loca
& corpora, non autem umbram facere, nisi per accidens suâ absen-
tiâ.e45-11Ita & Sol Philosophicus cum sua umbra facit diem, hoc est, lucẽlucem
& noctem seu tenebras, nempe Latonam seu magnesiam, cujus
umbram ignito pharmaco delendam & comburendam esse tradit
Democritus, ut lib.libro 3 Aureæae mensæae patet in initio. e45-12Umbrarum uti-
litas in Astronomicis adeò magna est, ut sine iis illa scientia absolvi
vix possit, Chymici quoque suis umbris asscribunt, quod eorum ars
ad perfectionem veniat; e45-13Quid enim Sol hic sine umbra? Quod pi-
stillum sine campana: Illud quidem facit motum primum, ut soni-
tus detur, at hæaec dat sonitum; illud est plectrum, hæaec organum; il-
lud lingua, hoc os magnum: e45-14Umbra res vilissima est, non Enti pro-
xima, sic & Philosophorum umbra est quid nigrum nigrius nigro,
ut vocant, vel vilius algâ, non propter se, sed hominum opinionem &
copiam; e45-15Igne quid utilius, quid aqua preciosius, quid terra amabi-
lius, quæae dat flores & amabilia omnia? quid aëre jucundius, quo in-
tercluso, omnia jucunda esse desinunt: e45-16Attamen, quia prostent ad
hominum usus in latè patentibus suis sphæaeris, vilissima censetur,
præaeposterâ imaginatione. e45-17Sic & umbra taxatur & communis &
Philosophica; Qui in umbris subterraneis diu degunt, si in claram
solis lucem subitò producantur, amittunt visum & aciem oculo-
rum; Ita qui in sola umbra Philosophica morantur & operantur, nec
ei solem adjungunt, judicio & oculis menis privantur: effectúque
frustrantur. e45-18In meridiem sole cœoelesti elevato major est calor, est &
minor umbra; sic quoque hic calore aucto diminuitur umbra & è-
converso; e45-19Incipiendum itaque sole à meridionali latere ad nostrum
verticem se iterum flectente, in Capricorno; & prima operatio us-
que ad Arietem erit absoluta, tum incipit opus mulierum, usque ad
Leonem; & post labor ex labore provenit, donec annus capite cau-
dam apprehendat, ut anguis, hoc est, absolutus sit.

html.head: s Atalanta Fugiens (Maier Edition. transcription) Facsimile Copy. Emblem

div.h1:
Zween Adler / einer von Often / der ander von Westen
kommen zusammen.

div.span: Der Jupiter Delphis zween Adler hat auß gesendet /
Gegen Auffgang und Niedergang so fern die Erd sich endet /
Dieweil das Mittel der Erdn wolt wissen und verstehen /
Welch (wie man sagt) zugleich zu Delphis wider gesehen /
Es seijnd aber zween Schein / dieser von Osten und der von Westen /
Welche zusammen kommen und in ein'neinen sich befesten.

div.h1: Aquilæae duæae, una ab ortu, altera ab occasu conveniunt.

div.span: Jupiter è Delphis aquilas misisse gemellas
Fertur ad Eôas Occiduásque plagas:
Dum medium explorare locum desiderat Orbis,
(Fama ut habet) Delphos hæae rediêre simul.
Ast illæae lapides bini sunt, unus ab ortu,
Alter ab occasu, qui bene conveniunt.

div.div:
e46-01Apollinem antiquissimum ex Vulcano natum, Athenarum cu-
stodem tradit Cicero lib.libro de natura Deorum. e46-02Quæae quidem o-
pinio, si ut debet, ad allegoriam transferatur, est verissima; Quia
Vulcanus Solem Philosophicum, qui Apollo est, producit. e46-03Sed præae-
valuit, quod ex Jove natus sit; Cùm verò Latona utero gestaret ge-
mellos Apollinem & Dianam, quos ex Jove conceperat, Juno Zelo-
typa Pythonem horrendæae vastitatis serpentem immisit, qui gravi-
dam prosequeretur & vexaret. e46-04Mulier misera post diutinos errores
tandem navigio delata in insulam Ortygiam, ad sororem suam A-
steriem, quæae in ea regnabat: Cúmque ea insula ferè tota mari inun-
daretur, parturienti Latonæae locum dedit, unde Delus dicta, quæae
Ἄδηλος erat antea. e46-05Ibi igitur enixa pueros; prima prodiit ex utero
Diana, eaq́ue se obstetricem matri in partu fratris Apollinis labo-
ranti præaebuit; Unde factum est, ut præaegnantes in puerperio ejus
Numen invocarent, eamq́ue vel Lucinam vel Ilithyiam vocave-
runt, quod lucem natis infantibus apertis eorum oculis ostenderet:
e46-06Apollo igitur natus, & adultus Pythonem matris vexatorem sagittis
confecit & Cyclopes occîdit, quod fulmen Jovi fabricassent ad in-
terficiendum ejus filium ÆAesculapium, quem Jupiter fulminatum
ad inferos destrusit, propterea quod Hippolytum ab equis discer-
ptum in vitam restituisset. e46-07Hæaec esse merè Chymica, multis in locis
demonstravimus. Latona enim, Cynthia, Apollo & Python, sunt re-
quisita artis, quæae eo modo se habent invicem, ut narratum est. e46-08Cùm
verò hæaec ab antiquissimis Poëtis, ut Orpheo, Lino, Museao, Home-
ro, scriptis vulgata essent, apud ignaros occasionem religioni & ve-
nerationi Apollinis præaebuerunt. e46-09Hinc in multis locis Europæae & A-
siæae cultus est Apollo, eiq́ue erecta templa innumera. e46-10Præaecipuè verò
Delphis antiqua religione venerandum habuit templum, in quo
statuæae plurimæae ex auro solido & argento magni ponderis & artifi-
cii à regibus & principibus repositæae erant, cum aliis donariis pre-
ciosissimis, quæae ab omnis status hominibus religionis causa in sacra-
riis recondita erant. e46-11Pausanias refert sceleton aheneum artificii ad-
mirandi appensum tholo templi fuisse ab Hippocrate: Apollini

quoque sacratus fuit ille celebris tripes, à Pelope, dum uxorem Hip-
podamiam duceret Oenomai regis Elidis filiam, quem Tripodem
fabricârat Mulciber & Pelopi donaverat. e46-12Hic in medio templi ere-
ctus erat, in quo insidens Pythia afflatum Dæaemonis erumpentis è
profundo hiatu excipiebat, quo correpta vaticinabatur,& responsa
dabat sciscitantibus rerum futurarum eventus. e46-13Fuere autem Del-
phi in Bœoeotica ad radice Parnassi siti. Templo vicinus fuit fons fa-
tidicus, Cassiotis, cui si faces ardentes admoverentur, eas extingue-
bat: si procul essent remotæae, subitò accendebantur, & flammas cõ-
cipiebantcon-
cipiebant. e46-14Ejusq́ue fontis aqua pota vim vaticinandi præaebebat; sed
tamen brevioris vitæae reddebantur ejus aquæae potores. e46-15Cùm itaque
concursus fiere ex omnibus Europæae, Asiæaeq́ue partibus ad oracu-
lum Delphicum, poëtæae eum locum, nẽpenempe Parnassum esse in medio
terræae fabulati sunt; idq́;idque ad exemplo Jovis probarunt, qui duab.duabus aɋ-
lisaqui-
lis emissis id experimentatus fuerat: e46-16Verùm cùm hæaec res historiæae fi-
de non nitatur, non à veritate alienum est, eam chymicis asscribere,
præaesertim cùm totus Apollo, ut dictum, sit chymicus origine, licet
dæaemon postea hominum suꝑstitionemsuperstitionem sub eo nomine confirmârit
& vaticinia dederit. e46-17Duæae aquilæae sunt duo lapides, ex quib.quibus unus ab
oriente, alter ab occidente venit; ꝙquod Philos.Philosophi multis modis demõstrâ-
runtdemonstra-
runt. e46-18Illas Jupiter emisit utpote suas armigeras. Aquila autem Apol-
lini seu Soli amica videtur, quia pullos suos probat ad Solem, quem si
sustinere nequeant, ut degeneres excludit. e46-19Ejus pennæae aliis reb.rebus cõ-
sertaecon-
sertae dicuntur non putrescere, & aliarum avium pennas devorare,
facilè inaurationem admiitere. e46-20Non senio, nec æaegritudine moritur,
sed fame. Crescens n.enim rostri superioris aduncitas impedit, ne cibum
queat capere; quâ abjectâ in fontem ter se mergit, eoq́;eoque modo redi-
re fertur ad juventutem. e46-21Hinc Psalmographus: Renovabitur, ut
aquilæae, juventus tua: e46-22Ex volatilib.volatilibus nunquam fulmine tangitur. e46-23Pu
gna est illi in draconem, qui propterea ejus ova consectatur: e46-24Quæae o-
mnia ejus naturæae munera causam præaebuerunt, cur Philos.Philosophicam aquilam
in arte sua præaedicent, eíque lapidem assimilent, cujus rei cùm innu-
mera exempla in libris eorum sint obvia, hîc plura non adferemus.

html.head: s Atalanta Fugiens (Maier Edition. transcription) Facsimile Copy. Emblem

div.h1:
Der Wolff von Auffgange / und der Hund vom Nidergange
kommende / haben sich unter einander gebissen.

div.span: Der Wolff von Auffgang der Sonnen / aber der Hund kompt gelauf= fen
Vom Nidergang / diese beijd haben der Galln ein hauffen /
Der hat diesen / und dieser jenen im grossen Zorn gebissen /
Und haben ein den andern mit Wütigkeit zerissen /
Es seynd zween Stein / so werden umbsonst einem jeden gegeben /
Anallen Orten und Zeit / die behalt du gar eben.

div.h1:
Lupus ab Oriente & Canis ab Occidente venientes se
invicem momorderunt.

div.span: Hinc, ubi Sol oritur, Lupus advenit, ast ubi Ponte
Mergitur, inde canis, qui duo bile tument:
Hunc is, & hic illum, stimulante furore momordit,
Et rabidus rictu visus uterque fuit.
Sunt gemini hi lapides, gratis qui dantur ubique
Omnibus atque omni tempore, quos teneas.

div.div:
e47-01Philosophi multis in locis duorum meminêre lapidum gratis
nobis datorum, ut Isaac, Arnoldus & aliî, inter quos Avicenna
dicit eos in stercore jacere abjectos, neglectos vulgò, qui si conjun-
gantur, perficiant magisterium: e47-02Quidam attollunt Mercurium oc-
cidentalem, qui præaetulit se auro & illud vicit? Verùm omnium o-
ptimè Author cõsiliiconsilii conjugii solis & lunæae ex Aristotelis Epistola bi-
nos describit lapides, ubi dicit: e47-03Quod hujus artis duo sunt lapides, princi-
pales, albus & rubeus mirabilis naturæae: Albus in occasu solis incipit apparere
super facies aquarum, abscondens se usque ad mediam noctem & postea ver-
git in profundum: Rubeus verò ex opposito operatur, quia incipit ascendere
super aquiis in ortu solis usque ad meridiem & postea descendit in profundum.
e47-04Hi itaq;itaque lapides sunt ante dictæae aɋlaeaquilae à Jove Delphis emissæae; Hi quo-
que sunt lupus & canis, ex diversis seu oppositis terræae plagis venien-
tes, quorum unus momordit alterum, & ambo rabiosi facti sunt, vel-
uti testatur Rhasis in Epistola: e47-05Hi lapides sunt verissimum Bezoar
ex quibus præaestantissimum mittit India Orientalis ex ferarum
ventre depromptum, aliud sed minoris efficaciæae dat India Occi-
dentalis, Peruana, ex cicuribus animalibus acceptum; e47-06Sic oriens
dat lupum atrocissimum, occidens canem hominibus familiarem,
hoc est, Sulphur ab Eoo, Mercurius ab Hesperio tractu venit; ex
quibus hic mollis & tractabilis, illud cholericum & iracundum exi-
stit: e47-07Qui duo quàm primum se invicem offendunt, in mutuos mor-
sus incidunt: Canis verò magnitudine insignis primam victoriam
obtinet prostrando lupum & semianimem reddendo: e47-08At lupus vi-
res recolligens post canem dejicit eíque dejecto instat usque ad in-
ternecionem; e47-09Interim non minora vulnera nec minus lethalia, quãquam
intulerat cani, ab eo recipiens, donec se mutuis conficiant & interi-
mant morsibus: e47-10De lupo Rosinus ad Euthiciam; inquit quod sit miles
victor duorum roboratus multi precii & intensissimi roboris, perforãsperforans corpo-
ra cum iis obviat, & est albus apparitione, rubeus experimento, estɋ́estque mas
qui lunam duxit in uxorem, quem nonnulli putant aurum esse preciosissimæae
cõnexionisconnexionis, cujus congelatum nunquam dissolvitur, neque vestigia delentur
quod Deus sanctis Philosophis & electis largitus est: Scito, quod natura cepit

comparem ut inimicum: Hæaec ille. e47-11Et mox: quod sulphur, inquit, fortissimam
est & ad versus ignem pugnans quod continet & continetur: Ex his nam-
que conjunctis color preciosissimus exit, & nunquam potest sulphur, quod
naturaliter fugit, postea fugere eo quod perforavit illud anima similiter &
perforavit & mixta est animæae tinctura corpori, & corpus animam continuit
& naturale fugere prohibuit. e47-12Et deinde quæaerenti, quis lapidum sit fortior,
respondet: Lapis qui non est lapis fortior est altero inimico: rubrum verò
est fortius illo quod sua fortitudine socios roboravit. e47-13Lupus itaque Orien-
talis fortior est cane occidentali, quamvis victoriæae non potiatur ef-
fectu, sed una cum inimico occidat: Ex utrisque verò fit venenum
tingens: e47-14Differentia inter lupum & canem exigua est, cùm molos-
sus seu præaegrandis canis lupinam formam & speciem ostendat, ita
ut lupus origine, sed longa progeneratione cicur factus videatur:
e47-15Eodem modo sulphur & mecurius parùm differunt inter se; quia
illud ex hoc, vel hic ex illo ortum ducat: Mercuruis quidem sulphur
genuit, at sulphur Mercurium purgavit & talem reddidit: e47-16De his
idem Rosinus, dum quæaerit Unde veniat ejus color? respondet, ex ejus in-
tensissima amaritudine: e47-17Et illa Unde venit ejus amaritudo & intensio? re-
spondet, ex ejus metalli impuritate: e47-18Et illa: nunquam ejus colore rubeus su-
pereminet? respondet Etiam: e47-19Et illa: nunquam etiam est igne calidior?
respondet: ignis ad respectum illius est tanquam aqua ad respectum ignis.
e47-20Et illa: Igne nè est fortior? respondet, non. e47-21Et illa: Quare ergo asseris, eum
igne esse fortiorem? Respondet, eò quod ignibus sibi ipsis obviantibus alter
alterum comedit. e47-22Patet itaque quod alter alterius alimentum fiat &
cibus, & quantum uni decrescat tantum alteri accrescat, donec ac-
crescens præaevaleat & draco serpentem devorârit: e47-23In magnis præaeli-
is sæaepè contingit, ut stragem majorem passi campum & victoriam
obtineãtobtineant; e47-24Ita & canis quãvisquamvis prostratus non tamen victus occubuit
omnino, cùm hostem adeò strictè teneat, ut ille absque hoc vivere,
nec hic absque illo mori possit.

html.head: s Atalanta Fugiens (Maier Edition. transcription) Facsimile Copy. Emblem

div.h3: FUGA XLVIII. in 5. seu 12. suprà. vertendo simplicem. ac initio.
div.h1:
Der König von getrunckenem Wasser bekompt ein
Kranckheit / von Arzten aber curiret,
die Gesundheit.

div.span: Einm König von Gut vñvon Leuten mächtig ein Brunnwasser für allen /
So er den Dienern befohl zubringen / thät gefallen /
Diß trunck er offt / biß daß er davon die Adern fund beschwerd
Ganz ungestalt / von Aerzten berümpt auffgenommen werd /
Von welchen wie er purgirt durch Schwiz / Stuel und auch durch den Mund
Wie Rosen seynt erscheint seine Wangen roth zur Stund /

div.h1:
Rex ab aquis potatis morbum, à medicis curatus
sanitatem obtinet.

div.span: Divitius populísque potens Rex fontis amavit,
Portari à servis quas sibi poscit, aquas:
Has bibit & rebibit venas mox inde repletus
Discolor à claris suscipitur medicis;
A quibus ut purgatus erat, sudoribus, alvo,
Oréque, mox tincta est utraque mala rosis.

div.div:
e48-01Xerxes ille potentissimus Persarum rex, cùm per sicca & inculta
loca sub æaestu exercitum duceret sitibundus haustum aquæae tur-
bidæae à quodam milite oblatum non respuit, sed gratissimè bibit,
portantemq́ue id donarii munere amplissimo ornavit. e48-02Et sanè si quis
hoc ipso tempore (ut quorundam historiæae recentissimæae testantur)
per fines Persiæae peregrinetur, rarissimè fontes aquæae dulcis invenire
dicitur, cùm aquęaquae stagnãtesstagnantes sint salsęsalsae, ac ipsum solũsolum in superficie salse-
dinem offerat copiosissimam: e48-03Eo modo Rex, cujus meminerunt
Philosophi siti vexatus, mandavit aquæae dulcis sibi copiam fieri; quãquam
allatam bibit ad satietatem; veluti ex Merlini allegoria cuivis con-
stat. e48-04Curatio regis æaegri & discolorati suscipitur à medicis diversis:
ÆAegyptii suis medicinis propinatis moverunt humores adhuc cru-
dos, quos Hippocrates priùs concoctos purgari debere asserit, nisi
sint fluxibiles & vagi. e48-05Tum enim mox educendi sunt, ne in partes
aut viscera nobiliora fortè impetum faciant & ruant. e48-06Hinc regi sym-
ptomata periculosa, utpote lipothymia & syncope obvenerunt. e48-07A-
lexandrini verò medici, postremò advenientes in morbo chronico,
feliciores sunt habiti, qui regem pristinæae sanitati restituerunt. e48-08Tanto
mederi regí est operæae precium, qui medico suo sanus factus benevo-
lam præaebet manum & faciem serenam. e48-09Legimus multorum cura-
tiones optimè fuisse recompensatas à regibus diversis, uti Democi-
dis à Polycrate Samiorum tyranno talentis duobus, Erasistrati (quẽquem
Plinius scribit, fuisse discipulum Chrysippi, ex Aristotelis filia geni-
tum) propter Antiochum regem, ex amore Stratonices novercæae æae-
grum sanatum, centum talentis à filio ejus Ptolemæaeo, ut Jacobi Co-
cterii, medici Galli regis Ludoici II. à quo quator millia coronato-
rum singulis mensibus pro stipendio accepti, aliorumq́ue recentio-
rum non faciamus mentionem; sed hujus regis sanatio adhuc longè
majori mercede aut præaemio recompensatur. e48-10Ita enim apud Rosa-
rium Hermes & Geber; Qui hanc, inquiunt, artem semel perfece-
rit, si deberet vivere mille millibus annis, & singulis diebus nutrire
quatuor millia hominum, non egeret.e48-11Hoc confirmat Senior, dicẽsdicens:
Est ita dives habens lapidẽlapidem, de quo Elixir fit, sicut qui habet ignem,

potest dare ignem, cui vult, & quando vult, & quantum vult sine suo
periculo & defectu. e48-12Democriti pater adeò dives fuit, ut exercitui
Xerxis Epulum dederit, Pythius quidam opulentissimus, obtulit
eidem stipendium totius exercitus & commeatum ad menses quin-
que, si modò unum ex quique filiis, natu minorem, qui suæae senectu-
tis esse solatium, ne in castra regia ire cogeretur, domi retinere lice-
ret; e48-13sed barbarus rex indignissimè petitionem Pythii ferens, jussit mi-
norem natu filium in duas partes dissectum palis utrimque ad viam
regiam adfigi, per quam totus exercitus transiturus erat, ut annotat
Sabellicus lib.libro 2. Ennead.Enneadis 3. e48-14Sed horum divitiæae nihil ad opes hujus
Regis, quæae sunt absque dimensione & numero. e48-15Hunc sanatum &
ab aquis liberatum Reges omnes, & potentes aliarum regionum
honoraverunt & timuerunt. e48-16Et quando volebant videre de mirabi-
libus ejus, ponebant in crucibulo unciam unam Mercurii bene loti
& projiciebant desuper tanquam unum granum milii de unguibus
vel de capillis aut sanguine suo, & sufflabant leviter cum carbonibus,
dimittebant eum infrigidari cum eis, & inveniebant lapidem, qua-
lem scio. e48-17Hic est ille, cujus Bernhardus Comes meminit, quod sex
suis aulicis tantundem regni det, quantum ipse possidet, si modò ex-
pectent, donec ipse in balneo juventutem recuperârit, & vestibus
variis, nempe thorace nigro, indusio albo & sanguine purpureo or-
natus sit; tum enim singulis de sanguine suo daturum, ipsósque sua-
rum divitiarum participes facturum se pollicetur.

html.head: s Atalanta Fugiens (Maier Edition. transcription) Facsimile Copy. Emblem

div.h3: FUGA XLIX. in 5. suprà. vertendo Basin seu fugientem vocem et incipiendo ab initio in d. sic vertendo simplicem et incipiendo in fine g.
div.h1:
& incipiendo ab initio in d. sic vertendo simplicem
& incipiendo in fine g.
Der Philosophische Kind erkennet drey Vätter /
wie der Orion.

div.span: Das Phœoebus, Mercurius und der Feiurgott / wie Fablen zeigen an /
Haben in ein Kindes Haut ihrn kräfftigen Samen gethan /
Und seynd drey Vätter zugleich geworden deß grossen Orions,
Also sagt man / daß da seynd drey Vätter der Weißheit Sohns /
Denn die Sonn der erste / Vulcanus der ander wirt erkennet /
Und der Künstler der dritt / dessn Vatter ist genennet.

div.h1: Infans Philosophicus tres agnoscit patres, ut Orion.

div.span: Fabula narratur, Phœoebus, Vulcanus & Hermes
In pellem bubulam semina quod suerint;
Trésque Patres fuerint magni simul Orionis:
Quin Sobolem Sophiæae sic tripatrem esse ferunt:
Sol etenim primus, Vulcanus at esse secundus
Dicitur, huic præaestans tertius arte pater.

div.div:
e49-01Mulieres, quæae se variis prostituunt viris, rarò sobolem viva-
cem concipiunt ex confusione diversorum seminum. e49-02Natura
enim in generatione hominis & animalium plæaerorumque non ad-
mittit superfœoetationem, nisi fortè rarissimè: e49-03Hinc ex unico patre &
matre proles quæaecunque nascitur, sive sit una aut plures, ut quoque
ex historiis & eventu aliter judicantium patet, inprimis Margaritæae
illius Hermanni comitis Hennebergiæae uxoris, quæae anno 1276. tre-
centos & sexaginta quinque enixa est pueros, quorum omnium ba-
ptisatorum, & masculorum, Johannis, fœoeminarum Elisabethæae no-
mine vocatorum, post demortuorum sepultura in Lausdunensi
templo, uno miliari distante Haga comitum versus mare, in Hol-
landia, adhuc cum pelvi æaerea, in qua baptizati sint, & inscriptione
historiæae, adhuc visitur: e49-04causam dicunt, quod Comitissa videns pau-
perculam mulierem gemellos in ulnis gestare, eam adulteram vo-
cârit, quasi impossibile fit, ut plures liberi uno conceptu ex uno vi-
ro, sed ex diversis, necessariò ederentur: e49-05Unde imprecatione facta
à paupere, quæae se ab eo crimine puram noverat, quotquot dies in
anno sunt, tot ipsa concepit in utero uno tempore & ex uno viro: e49-06Mi-
raculum hoc quidem est, at naturale opus, quod ex divinia ultione
contigit: e49-07In opere autem Philosophico quod alias naturæae adver-
sum est, facilè admittitur sub allegoriæae vestimento: Hic enim unus
fœoetus tres dicitur habere patres vel etiam binos, ut & matres. e49-08Hinc
Raymundus, ut citat Rosarius, noster, inquit, infans habet duos
patres & duas matres: & quia ipse charè nutritus est ex tota substan-
tia in igne, propter quod nunquam moritur: e49-09Ita Dionysus seu Bac-
chus bimater appellatur, quem immaturum combustâ matre ex e-
jus vẽtreventre eripuit & femori suo insuit, ut pater mater factus sit: e49-10Sed
hæaec magis declarãturdeclarantur in Orionis conceptu, ɋqui ex Apollinis, Vulcani
& Mercurii commixtis seminibus in pelle bubula inclusis per 10
menses, natus dicitur: e49-11Monstrosa hæaec essent omnino, non tantùm
fabulosa, nisi arcanum naturæae sub his involucris lateret, non omnib.omnibus
obvium. Lullius in Theorica testamenti eidem fœoetui Philosophico
tot & ferè eosdem attribuit patres, nempe Solem, qui est Apollo

sive Sol cœoelestis est primus hujus generationis author, qui virtute
sua inenarrabili & occulta seu astrali operatur in materiam quan-
dam Philosophis notam, tanquam in matricem mulieris, in eáque
producit filium seu fœoetum sibi similem, cui postea sua arma & in-
signia virtutum, paterno jure, tradet & relinquet, hoc est, immatura
maturandi & non tincta nec purgata, tingendi & purgandi poten-
tiam. e49-12Quicquid enim Sol in mille annis perficit, hoc filius ejus in di-
midia hora præaestabit; Propterea ut vis millecuplo fortior in eo fiat
quàm in Sole, pater eum Vulcano in disciplinam tradit & artifici si-
mul, ut ab his ejus generosa indoles excolatur & viribus multiplice-
tur; siquidem constet à teneris assuescere multum esse: e49-13Sic Achilles
Jason, Hercules Chironi erudiendi fuêre traditi eandem ob inten-
tionem. e49-14Milo enim Crotoniata, qui puer vitulum gestavit, vir bo-
vem sustulit ex consuetudine. e49-15Non injuriâ autem, præaeter Solem,
Vulcanus & artifex hujus pueri vocantur patres, quia primus ut es-
set, hi ut talis & tantus, effecerunt: e49-16Nec verò æaequivalens didactron
magistris solvi potest ob institutionem, ut nec præaemium parenti-
bus ob generationem. Hi corpus, illi animum concinnant. e49-17Si ani-
mus potior est corpore, nec illis minor | referẽdareferenda est gratia, quàm his.
e49-18In Orionis verò ortu Mercurius materiam, Apollo formam, & Vul-
canus calorem seu efficientem causam externam præaebuit. e49-19Sic quoq;quoque
in opere Philosophico fieri convenit, ut tres patres in unam sobolem
conspirasse videantur, in qua Philosophorum sint delitiæae.

html.head: s Atalanta Fugiens (Maier Edition. transcription) Facsimile Copy. Emblem

div.h1:
Der Drache hat das Weib und sie ihn umgebracht /
und werden beijde mit Blut ubergossen.

div.span: Laß graben ein Grab tieff dem gifftigen Drachen / dem das Weib
Sol werden verbunden festiglich an ihrem Leib /
Dieweiler / wieder Mann mit ihr der Liebe geniessen werd /
Stirbet sie und wirt zugleich mit ihm begrabn in die Erd /
Daher er auch stirbet / und wirt mit rothem Blut begossen /
Diß ist deines Wercks wahrer Weg unverdrossen.

div.h1:
Draco mulierem, & hæaec illum interimit, simulque
saunguine perfunduntur.

div.span: Alta venoso fodiatur tumba Draconi,
Cui mulier nexu sit bene vincta suo:
Ille maritalis dum carpit gaudia lecti,
Hæaec moritur, cum qua sit Draco tectus humo.
Illius hinc corpus morti datur, atque curore
Tingitur: Hæaec operis semita vera tui est.

div.div:
e50-01 Draconum mansio in cavernis terræae est, hominum verò supra
terram in aëre proximo; quæae duo sunt elementa contraria &
jubentur à Philosophis conjugi, ut actio unius in aliud fiat: e50-02 Per mu-
lierem verò alii intelligunt, ut Basilius clave 2. Non enim utile est, in-
quit, aquilæae nidum suum in alpibus ponere: Nam pulli ejus præae frigore nivis
in summitate montium morerentur: e50-03 Quod si verò aquilæae draconem frigi-
dum qui suam habitationem in petris longo tempore habuit, & ex terræae spe-
luncis prorepit, addas, ambósque in infernalem sellam ponas, tum Pluto ven-
tum afflabit, & ex frigido dracone igneum spiritum volatilem eliciet, qui suo
magno calore aquilæae pennas cumburet, ac sudorificum balneum excitabit a-
deò ut nix in summis montibus colliquescat, & aqua fiat; quo minerabile bal-
neum bene præaeparetur, & regi fortunam ac sanitatem tribuat. e50-04 Admirabile
sanè est, quod draco frigidus spiritum ignem de se mittet; Id tamen
verum esse experientia declarat in serpentibus combustis, qui flam-
mam venenosam assistentes inficientem emittunt. e50-05 Nec frustrà dra-
cones thesaurorum chymicorum custodes flammivomi dicuntur,
ut aurei velleris, hortorum Hesperidum, Cadmi, & his similes. e50-06 Degit
autem hic draco in angustis petrarum subterranearum locis, quem
ibi capere oportet, & aquilæae seu mulieri adjungere, huic in sepul-
chro, illi, si mavis, in nido: Natura enim draconis est aliàs, ut insidie-
tur ovis aquilinis, cúmque aquila internecinum bellum gerat. e50-07 Dra-
conem aliquando amasse puellam, cúmque ea concubuisse, ex Grę-
cisGrae-
cis scriptoribus sunt, qui tradant. Quid mirum igitur, si Philos.Philosophi velint,
draconem suum cum muliere in una caverna cõcludiconcludi debere? e50-08 Gre-
verus dracones rubeos & nigros in imâ montis voragine conjungit,
ignéque adurit, & pereuntibus nigris, dicit montis custodem, undi-
quaque illos conquirere,& in montem inferre. e50-09 Merlinus in sua visio-
ne (nisi illa sit supposititia) mentionẽmentionem facit draconis albi & rubei; Hi
dracones, quicunque sint, sive un sit mulier, seu draco fœoemina, in se
invicem agunt, donec utrique moriantur, & sanguinem emittant
ex vulneribus, quo perfunduntur. Intelligitur verò hîc per draco-
ne, elementum terræae & ignis, & per mulierem, aëris & aquæae; e50-10 Un-
de Clangor buccinæae dicit, quod draco est materia in fundo remanens

post distillationem aquæae ab ea: e50-11 Et ex Hermete: Aqua aëris inter cœoelum &
terram existens est vita unius cujusque rei. Ipsa enim aqua solvit corpus in spi-
ritum,& de mortuo facit vivum, & facit matrimonium inter virum &
mulierem. Etenim totum benficium artis facit: e50-12 De terra quoque sic in-
quit. Et intellige adhuc, quod ista propria terra quàm calcamus non est ve-
rum elementum, imò est elementata à suo vero quinto elemento: Nec recedit
quinta substantia elementalis à suo corpore elementato de quo terra est for-
mata. e50-13 Et mox. Sed in centro terræae est virgo & elementum verum, quod i-
gnis non poterit ardere: Hic est draco, de quo loquimur, in centrum usque
terræae se insinuans, ubi cùm magnus sit calor, æaestum flammeum intra se conci-
pit, quo mulierem seu aquiliam comburit. e50-14 Mulier verò vel aquila, aqua
est aëria; quàm nonnulli aquilam albam seu cœoelestem vocant, & ex
Mercurio vulgari, vel salibus sublimatis conficere satagunt, sequen-
tes in eo ductum quorundam cæaecorum in hac arte, lynceos se simu-
lantium; e50-15 Sed amen dico tibi, inquit Bernhardus Comes in Epist.Epistula quod
nulla aqua naturali reductione speciem metallicam dissolvit, nisi illa quæae per-
manet ei in materia & forma, & quam metalla ipsa possunt recongelare: e50-16 Et mox. Nec corporibus pertinet aqua in solutionibus, quæae iis in congelationibus
non permanet: e50-17 Et paulò post: Amen dico tibi, quod oleum naturas natura-
iter incerans & conjugens ac naturaliter introducens medicinam in alia
corpora tingenda, non componitur ex alio extraneo, sed tantùm ex visceribus
corporis dissolvendi: e50-18 Aquila itaque & mulier, nec non draco ac totius
ferè artis arcana hoc percepto, intelliguntur, quæae fortè nimis aper-
to naturæae gremio hactenus doctrinæae filiis exposuimus & declaravi-
mus, ut hinc Deo sit gloria.

html.head: s Atalanta Fugiens (Maier Edition. transcription) Facsimile Copy. Emblem

div.span: Hesperii precium juvenis tulit impiger horti
Dante Deâ pomum Cypride tergeminum:
IdqIdque sequens fugientis humo glomeravit ad ora
Virginis, hinc tardas contrahit illa moras:
Mox micat is, micat hæaec mo ante fugacior Euris,
Alteratum spargens aurea dona solo,
Ille morabatur vestigia lenta puellæae
Rursus, at hæaec rursus dat sua terga fugæae;
Tertia donec amans iterârit pondera, cessit
Victori merces hinc Atalanta suo.
Hippomenes virtus est sulphuris, illa fugacis
Mercurii, in cursu femina victa mare est.
Qui postquam cupido se complectuntur amore
In fano Cybeles, corrigit ira Deam;
Pelle leonina vindex & vestiit ambos,
Inde rubent posthac corpore, suntqsuntque feri.
Hujus ut exprimeret simulacra simillima cursus
Voce tibi ternâ dat mea Musa fugas:
Una manet simplex, pomúmque refert remorans vox,
Altera sed fugiens, tertia ritè sequens.
Auribus ista tuis, oculísque Emblemata prostent,
At ratio arcanas expetat inde notas:
Sensibus hæaec objecta tuli, intellectus ut illis
Illicibus caperet, quæae preciosa latent.
Orbis quicquid opum, vel habet Medicina salutis,
Omne Leo geminus suppeditare potest.

html.head: s Atalanta Fugiens (Maier Edition. transcription) Facsimile Copy. Emblem

body.div:
3
Amplissimo, Celeberrimo & Excellentissimo
Mülhausensis
in Thuringia Imperialis
Reipublicæae Senatorio ordini,
Viris Virtute, Doctrinâ, & verâ animi Nobilitate
præaestantissimis;
Nec non ejusdem Syndico vigilantissimo,
Christophoro
Reinart utriusque Juris Doctori
Consultiss.Consultissimo P.Poetae C.Coronato Caes.Caesareo
suaviss.suavissimo etcetcaetera.
a
Dominis suis semper honorificè colendis omnibus & singulis hoc benevo-
lentiæae suæae gratitudinisqgratitudinisque qualecunque tecmerion, dicat, dedicat &
obfert officiosissimè.
ded-01Michael Majerus Med.Medicinarum D.Doctor Imper.Imperialis Consist.Consistorii Com.Comes E.Eques E.Exemptus P.Poeta CCoronatus.
ded-02Viri amplissimi consultissimíq;consultissimique De Tri-
pode illo Pelopi sponso, cum Hippoda-
miam Oënomai Regis Elidis filiam in u-
xorem duceret, à Vulcano dono dato, nar-
rant, quod, cùm singularis artificii esset, à
Pelope Apollini Pythio Delphis iterùm oblatus sit, ex
quo deinde per virginiem afflatu illius Dei oracula sint e-
4
dita: ded-03Ita cùm mihi hic Tripes à Vulcano elaboratus
ad manum venerit, Pelopis exemplo motus, illum di-
gnissimo loco & ordini consecrare & obferre decrevi, &
quidem ante omnes alios, Vestris Amplituddd.Amplitudissimis & Excel-
centtt.Excel-
centissimis non quidem eo consilio, ut unde Oracula depro-
mantur (quamvis nec ea, at chymica, hîc desyderari pos-
sint) sed ut animi mei promptitudinem voluntatemq́;voluntatemque
benevolam aliquo modo erga eas publicè testarer, quæae
ante paucos annos in transitu mihi tum Cæaesareæae Maje-
stati Rudolpho II. divæae memoriæae à consiliis medicis
existenti, quo animo erga Dominum essetis, ministro
declarare volueritis, nempe optimo & vestro statu di-
gnissimo: ded-04A quo tempore semper non solùm verbis,
quoad potui, vestras virtutes apud exteros ornavi, sed in
hoc quoque incubui, ut re ipsa mentem meam apertiùs
iisdem patefacerem, & uberiùs effunderem. ded-05Quod cùm
non aliter, quàm literario quopiam Xeniolo fieri posse
præaesenserim, ac nonnihil operæae in hac Atalanta fugien-
te consumpserim, omne id, qualecunque sit, Vestris
Amplituddd.Amplitudissimis & Excellenttt.Excellentissimis dicare volui, in hoc imitatus
nostri & antiqui temporis scriptores, qui nunquam sine
Scipione, duce aut comite in vulgus prodire, sive per ora
virûm ambulare voluerunt: Si enim cecidissent, quis
subvenisset illis? ded-06Quæaeso, ut hujus opusculi Patronos mi-
hi vos appellare liceat, non quod huic, verè dubio, stu-
dio manum aut mentem, quantum sciam, adhibueritis,
5
(nec enim à gravissimis negotiis tantùm superfuit otii)
sed quia satis mihi videremini, ad quamvis doctrinæae
partem tuendam, mihiq́;mihique non alia materia sive dignior
sive honestior (excluso abusu) pro tempore occurrerit.
ded-07Quicquid sit, vos meos conatus, non pro chartæae vilitate,
sed animi mei candore (quod scio) æaestimabitis, méque
inter vestrarum Amplituddd.Amplitudissimarum observantissimos impo-
sterum habebitis & numberabitis. ded-08Valete, Dabam
Francofurti ad Mœoenum, Anno 1617. Mense Augusto.

11
Michael Majerus Comes Imperialis Con-
sistorii etcetcaetera: PhilosophPhilosophiae: et Medicinarum

html.head: s Atalanta Fugiens (Maier Edition. transcription) Facsimile Copy. Emblem

body.div:
06
pr-01Hominem, lectorem candide, universi compendium
sui compositione referre, in confesso est omnium,
& ternis vite generibus vivendis destinatum es-
se, nempe vegetabili in utero materno, ubi sal-
tem plantæae instar crescit & augmentatur; sensi-
bili, nimirum in hoc mundo, ubi maxima ex parte sensibus ducitur,
ceu reliqua animalia, à quibus differt, quod intellectu incipiat
uti, licet imperfectè; ac denique intelligibili, in altero mundo apud
Deum, eiq́ue assistentes intelligentias seu Angelos bonos; pr-02In præae-
senti vitâ, quò quis magis ad divinam naturam accedit, eò magis
rebus intellectu indagandis, subtilibus, miris & raris, gaudet &
delectatur: Et econtrà, quò quis ad pecuinũpecuinum genus magis declinat,
eò min his capitur, & sensui corporaliori astrictus est: pr-03Utro-
rumque videmus Exempla, quosdam illis, utpote doctiores, artibus
& scientiis politos esse deditos, quàmplurimos hisce, nempe volu-
ptatibus corporis, libidini, gulæae, pompæae externæae, & his similibus.
pr-04Ad excolendum autem intellectum Deus infinita arcana abdidit
in natura, quæae scientiis & artibus innumeris, ut ignis ex silice ex-
tunduntur, & in usum transferuntur: pr-05Inter hæaec sunt Chymica
7
secreta non postrema, sed post divinorum indagationem, omnium
prima & preciosissima, non circumforaneis deceptoribus & fucis
pseudo-chymicis (qui in his sunt asini ad lyram, quippe ad omni bo-
na doctrina & intentione alienissimi) sed ingeniis altioribus, libe-
raliter educatis, & ad [majora natis]majoranatis investiganda, cùm sint val-
dè subtilia, augusta, sacra, rara & abstrusa, ideoq́ue intellectu
comprehendenda priùs, quàm sensu, potiùs per contemplationem
profundam ex lectione authorum, eorumq́ue inter se & cum natu-
ræae operibus comparationem, quàm operationem sensitivam, seu
manualem experimentationem, quæae cœoeca est fine Theorica præae-
via: pr-06Post scientias huiusmodi intellectuales proximè numerantur,
quequae de visibili ac audibili objecto tractant, ut sun Optica seu per-
spectiva, & pictura loquens, nec non Musica sive vocalis
seu organica: pr-07In hac antiqui Philosophi adeò se exercuerunt, ut in-
doctus haberetur, & ad myrtumyrtum canere cogeretur, qui lyralyram recusasset
in conviviis, ut de Themistocle traditur: pr-08In Musica Socrates
institutus & ipse Plato, qui non harmonicè compositũcompositum eum statuit,
qui harmonia Musicali non gaudeat: pr-09In eâdem Pythagoras per-
celebris fuit, qui manè & vesperi musicæae symphonia ad compo-
nendos suorum discipulorum animos usus dicitur: pr-10Est enim Mu-
sicæae hæaec peculiaris vis, ut affectus excitet vel mulceat, pro diver-
so Musicali modo: pr-11Sic Phrygius Modus apud Græaecos diceba-
tur bellicosus propterea, quod in bello & in præaelio ineundo accinere-
tur, & singularem vim haberet ad animos militum concitandos;
cuius vice ad eundem usum nunc adhibetur Ionicus, qui olim
8
amatorius æaestimatus fuit (qualis nunc habetur Phrygius) unde
modos inter se mutatos conjicimus: pr-12Phrygio Timotheum
Milesium usum tradunt ad Alexandrum Magnum in rebus bel-
licis alacriorem & animosiorem reddendum, cujus Cicero meminit
2. de legiblegibus. pr-13Terpandrum verò Lesbium Ionico; qui accersi-
tus à Lacedæaemoniis, seditionibus inter se tumultuantibus suavi-
tate cantus eorum animos adeò delinivit, ut redirent in amici-
citiam & à seditione desisterent: Unde Lesbii cantores primas
semper meruerunt Spartanorum judicio: pr-14De Musica sic Fabius,
Musica, inquit, est honestum & jucundum oblectamentum libe-
ralibus ingeniis maximè dignum: pr-15Hæaec tria itaque sensuum magis
spiritualium, nempe visus & auditus, nec non intellectus ipsius
objecta, ut in uno quasi conspectu & complexu haberemus, & ma-
gis intelligendũintelligendum animis simul & semel insinuaremus, En conju-
ximus Opticam cum Musica & sensum cum intellectu, hoc est, ra-
ra visu & auditu cum chymicis emblematibus, quæae huic scientiæae
sunt propria. pr-16Cæaeteræae enim artes, si emblemata edant de moribus,
aur rebus aliis, quàm de naturæae arcanis, alienum hoc videtur ab
eorum scopo & fine, cùm intelligi omnibus velint & debeant;
pr-17Chemia nõnon itẽitem, quæae ut casta virgo per transennam, & veluti Dia-
na, non absq;absque veste variati coloris visenda est, propter causas alibi
expressas: pr-18Quatuor, inquam, hæaec, ficta, poëtica & allegorica, picta,
Emblematica, Veneri sive cupro, non sine Venere sue gratia, incisa,
Chymica secretissima, intellectu indaganda & denique Musicalia
rariora, simul & semel uno libro suscipias inq́ue tuum usum dicata
adhibeas, qui si potiùs intellectualis fuerit, quàm sensualis, eò uti
9
-
lior & jucundior olim futurus est: pr-19quod si verò primum sensui man-
cipatus, nullum est dubium quin à sensu ad intellectum transitus
fiet, tanquam per ostium: pr-20Nihil enim in intellectu esse dicitur, quod
non per sensum aliquem introiverit, cùm hominis recens nati in-
tellectus instar tabulæae rasæae habeatur, in qua nihil adhuc scriptum,
sed quod libet sensu mediante, tanquam stylo, scribi possit: pr-21Et vulgo
dicitur; Ignoti nulla cupido, quia oportet, ut intellectui, veluti dicta-
tori & arbitro, sensus indagatores & nuncii, omne scibile primitus
apportent & innotescere faciant, tanquãtanquam Excubitores ad (sua or-
gana) civitatis alicujus portas invigilãtesinvigilantes. pr-22De ratione inscriptionis
horum emblematũemblematum, ne & hæaec tibi monstrosa videatur & absona,
pauca adjiciam: pr-23Atalanta Poëtis celebrata est propter fugam,
quâ omnes procos in certamine antevertit, ideóque ipsis victis pro
virgine, præaemio victoriæae proposito, mors obtigit, donec ab Hippo-
mene, juvene audaciore & provido, superata & obtenta sit trium
malorum aureorum per vices inter currendum objectu, quæae dum
illa tolleret, præaeventa est ab eo, metam jam attingente: pr-24Hæaec Ata-
lanta ut fugit, sic una vox Musicalis semper fugit ante aliam &
altera insequitur, ut Hippomenes: pr-25In tertia tamen stabiliun-
tur & firmantur, quæae simplex est & unius valoris, tanquam
malo aureo: pr-26Hæaec eadem virgo merè Chymica est, nempe Mercu-
rius Philosophicus à sulfure aureo in fuga fixatus & retentus,
quem si quis sistere noverit, sponsam, quam ambit, habebit, sin mi-
nus, perditionem suarum rerum & interitum: pr-27Ex Hippome-
ne & Atalanta coëuntibus in templo Matris Deûm, hoc est, va-
se, fiunt leones, sive rubeum acquirunt colorem. pr-28Obtinuit quoque
10
hæaec virgo victoriam præae viris, apro quodam insignis magnitudinis
occiso, unde præaemio à Meleagro donata est: pr-29Apud Stethæaeum
ÆAesculapii fanum è saxo percusso aquam elicuit, quam sitibunda
bibit: pr-30Quæae cùm allegorica & Emblematica revera sint & nullo
modo historica, volui in hujus Heroinæae commemorationem intell-
lectualem hunc tractatum Emblematicum indigetare, præaesertim
cùm poma ei projecta ex hortis Hesperiis à Venere, suavitatis
Dea, Hippomeni fuerint ministrata: pr-30In modulis illis seu fugis
Musicis hoc observatum videtis, quod singula disticha ad tres il-
las voces adaptata convenienter canendo exprimi possint, in qui-
bus cùm uni simplici voci tot varietates fugarum sint accommo-
datæae, omnis cordatus & intelligens hanc quoque Emblematicam
quasi figurationem, in his, ut & in distichis adaptationẽadaptationem ad singu-
las voculas, boni consulet & pro nonnihilo reputabit: pr-31Si enim
mercatores nonnulli pro magna pecuniæae summa artificium picturæae
aliquod æaestimant & emunt, ubi soli oculi falluntur, cùm naturæae
propinquissimum judicent, quid ni literati has figuras, quæae & in-
tellecctui & sensibus pluribus inserviunt ita, ut magna inde spe-
randa sit utilitas præaeter oblectationem, in precio habeant & ma-
gni censeant? Vale.

Chymica,

cupro incisis, adjectisq́ue sententiis, Epigram-
matis & notis, partim auribus & recreationi
animi plus minus 50. Fugis Musicalibus trium
Vocum, quarum duæae ad unam simplicem melo-
diam distichis canendis peraptam, correspon-

head.title: Atalanta Fugiens (Beinecke Ms. transcription) Facsimile Copy. Emblem

h3.span: the first Embleme Emblem. Of the Secrets of Nature.

h1.span: 4 chars 1 charWind carryed carried him in his belly - - - -

div.div:
If Boreas once expand his windy wombe womb,
That th' the Infant in the world alive may come,
His prowesse prowess will the Heroes all outdoe outdo
In art, in hand, in mind, and body too.
Thinke Think him noe no Cœso, nor abortive brood,
Nor yet Agrippa, for his starre star was good.
*D Powell 1821

e01-01Hermes the most industrious inquisitor into every naturall natural secret doth
in his Smaragdine table elegantly, though concisely, describe the naturalle natural
worke work, where amongst other things hee he sayth: the wind carrys carries him in his
belly: as if hee he should say, Hee He, whose father is Sol, and mother Luna,
must, before hee he can be brought to light, be carryed carried by windy fumes, even
as a bird is caryed carried by the aire air, when it flyes flies: e01-02now from fumes or winds, (which
are nothing els else but aire air moved) coagulated is produced water, from which mixed
with earth doe do proceed all mineralls minerals and metalls metals: e01-03Yea these very things are
determined to consist and be imediately immediately coagulated of fumes: whether
therefore it be ascribed to water or fume, the thing is the same, because
they are both the matter of wind: e01-04the same may be sayd said of mineralls minerals
and metalls metals, though more remotely: now the quæstion question is; who hee he is, that
ought to be carryd carried by wind? e01-05I answer, Chymically, it is Sulphur, which is
carryd carried in Argent vive, as Lully in his booke book, Chapt 32 attests, and alle all the *
*Lully there.
The wind carryes carries
him in his belly, that
is, Sulphur is carryd carried
in ☿. and Chap. 47.
The Stone is fire
carryd carried in the belly
of aire. . . . .
rest; physically, it is an infant, which ought in a little time to be borne born into
the world: I say allso also Arithmetically, that it is the root of a Cube; Musically,
that it is the Disdiapason; Geometrically, that it is a punctum the begining beginning
of a running line; Astronomically, the center of the planets, Saturne Saturn,
Jupiter, and Mars: e01-06though these be different subjects, yet if they be
well compard compared together, they will easily demonstrate the offspring of wind,
which must be left to every mans industry more or lesse less. e01-07But I indigitate
the matter more plainly thus: every Mercury is compounded of fumes,
that is, of water elevating earth with it into an airy rarity, and of earth
forcing aire air to returne return into a watry watery earth or earthy water: e01-08for the Ele=
ments being alltogether altogether in it, and mixed, and subdued and reduced together
into a viscous nature, they doe do not easily recede one from the other,1 but
3either 5the 6volatile 2doe do 4follow 7above, 8or remayne remain below with the fixed, the
first whereof is evident in coḿon common Mercury, the other in the Philosophicall Philosophical
and fixed metalls metals: in these the fixed Elements doe do prædominate predominate over the volatile,
in ^that the volatile oversway the fixed: e01-09nor indeed is it without reason, that
Mercury is calld called and reputed the messenger, interpreter, and as it were the
running intermediate minister of the other Gods, with wings fitted to his
head and feet: for hee he is windy, and flyes flies through the aire air as wind itselfe itself,
as is coḿonly commonly and really confirmed to the damage of many men;

015e01-10but car=
rying a white wand girt with two Serpents crossewise crosswise, which can draw soules souls
out of bodyes bodies, and bring them backe back againe again, and doe do many such contrary
things, hee he exquisitely repræsents represents the Philosophicall Philosophical Mercury. e01-11Mercury there=
fore is wind, which takes Sulphur or Dionysius, or, if you had rather, Æscu=
lapius Aesculapius, beging yet an imperfect Embryo, out of the mothers belly, or even out*
*becomes Volatile
of the ashes of the mothers body burned, and carryes carries it thither, where it
may be matured; e01-12and the Embryo is Sulphur, which is infused into *
*digested & fix'd
the belly of Boreas by the cælestiall celestial Sunne Sun, that hee he may bring it
forth being matured, who in the compleat complete time of his cariage carriage produceth produces*
*the White & reddish
or 🜍
twins, one with white haire hair, called Calais, the other with red, named*
*x a
Zethe: e01-13these Sonns Sons of Boreas were (as Orpheus the Chymicall Chymical poet writes)
10Discourse i I.
with Jason among the Argonauts to carry away the golden fleece from Col=
chos: and Phineus the blind Prophet, infested by the Harpyes Harpies, could not be*
*Black
freed, but by the sayd said Sonns sons of Boreas, for which benefitt benefit obtained from
them, hee he, being gratefull grateful, declared the whole manner of the way to the
Argonauts: e01-14But the Harpyes Harpies are noe no other, than corrupting Sulphur, which
is driven away by the Sonns sons of Boreas, having attaind attained to full age, and of a
thing imperfect or molested with noxious birds is made perfect, not sub=
ject to that evill evil, which then shews shows to Jason the Physitian Physician the way to
obtaine obtain the golden fleece. e01-15These winds our countryman Basill amongst
others allso also takes notice of, and plainly sayth says: TheA doublewind ought to comearise;*
*absurdly described
that called Vulturnus, and after that one; then a single wind, called Notus, which mustwillblow*
*Naaman comes
from the north
from the East and South impetuously, whose motion ceasing, soe so as wa=
ter to be made of aire air, you maywillconfidently beleive believe, that a corporall corporal
thing will be made of a spirituall spiritual. e01-16And Ripley gate 8. sayth says, that
our Infant ought to be borne born againe again in aire air, that is, in the belly of
wind: e01-17Sayth Says Scala Philosophorum, degree 6. after the same sense thus:
You must know that the Sonne Son of the wise is borne born in the aire air: e01-18and
degree 8: Airy Spirits ascending together into the aire air doe do love them=one
selvesanother, as Hermes sayth says, the wind carryd carried him in its belly: because
the generation of our Sonne Son is made in the aire air, and being borne born
in the aire air is borne born wisely: for hee he ascends from earth to heaven, and
againe again descends to earth acquiring both the superiour superior and inferiour inferior
virtue. . . . . . . . . . . . . .

head.title: Atalanta Fugiens (Beinecke Ms. transcription) Facsimile Copy. Emblem

h3.span: Embleme Emblem 2. Of the Secrets of Nature.

h1.span: the earth is his Nurce Nurse.

div.div:
A courteous Wolfe Wolf to Romulus displayd displayed
Her milky duggs, to Jove a Goat, tis sayd said:
Nor is it strange to assert our mother Earth
Gave Sucke suck to th' tender Philosophicke Philosophic birth;
If beasts soe so small Heroes soe so great could breed,
How great will hee he be, whome whom the whole earth doth feed?

e02-01It is concluded by the Peripateticks Peripatetics, and Orthodox Philosophers, that the
thing nourishing is converted into the substance of the thing nourished, and
assimilated to it, not indeed before, but after the alteration of it, and that is ac=
counted an infallible axiome axiom: e02-02for how would the thing nourishing (which is all=
ready before the like and the same with the thing nourished) have need of
the mutation of its essence, which if it should happen, it would not remayne remain
the same nor the like; or how should those things, which cannot be assimilated
to the thing nourished, be taken for nutriment, e02-03such as are wood, stones and
the like? e02-04as therefore the first is vayne vain, soe so the other is contrary to nature; e02-05but
for an Infant new borne born to be nourished by the milke milk of animalls animals, is a thing
not repugnant to nature: because assimilation of it may be made, but far
more easily of the mothers, than of anothers: e02-06wherefore Physitians Physicians doe do con=
clude, that it conduceth conduces to the health, similitude of substance and manners,
as allso also strength of an Infant, if it be allwayes always nourished by the milke milk of its
owne own mother, on the contrary if by anothers. e02-07This is the harmony of every
nature, that like delights in its like, and followes follows its footsteps, soe so farre far as it
is able, in all things, with a certaine certain tacit consent and conspiration: e02-08the same
thing usually happens in the naturall natural worke work of the Philosophers, which is æqually equally
governed by nature in the conformation of it, as an infant in the mothers
wombe womb; e02-09and though a father and mother, and nurce nurse itself be by way of si=
militude ascribed to it, yet it is not more artificiall artificial, than the generation of
every animall animal: e02-10two seeds are by a certaine certain pleasant artifice joynd joined together
by animalls animals, and both humane human sexes, which being united doe do by successive
alteration produce an Embryo, which growes grows and is increased, acquires life
and motion, and then is nourished by milke milk: e02-11but necessary it is for the wo=
man in time of conception and imprægnation impregnation to carry herselfe herself temperately
in heat, meat and drinke drink, motion and rest, and other circumstances, otherwise
an abortion will follow, and destruction of the conceived Embryo, which
observation in six things not naturall natural, because it is præscribed prescribed by Physi=
tians Physicians according to their art, is allso also artificiall artificial. e02-12After the same manner if the
seeds be not joyned together in the Philosophicall Philosophical worke work, they ought to be
joyned joined: but if they could be found somewhere joyned joined together, as the seed
of the Cocke Cock and Henne Hen are had in an egge egg subsisting together in one
continent, then would the Philosophers worke work be yet more naturalle natural, than
the generation of animalls animals. e02-13But let us grant, as the Philosophers doe do assert,

019that one comes from the east and another from the west, and are made one,
what more is administred administered to them, than mixtiureon in their owne own vessell vessel, tem=
perate heat and nutriment? e02-14the vessell vessel is indeed artificiall artificial, but herein is
noe no difference, whether the nest be made by the Henne Hen herselfe herself, or dispo=
sed by a rusticke rusticcountry dame in an unsome certaine certain place, as coḿon common it is, the generation of
the eggs, and the hatching of chickens from them will be the same. e02-15Heat
is a naturall natural thing, whether it proceed from the temperate fire of fur=
naces, and putrefaction of dung, or from the Sunne Sun and aire air, or bowells bowels
of the mother, or elswhere elsewhere: thus the Ægyptian Egyptian doth by art administer
13Discourse 2.
naturall natural heat by his furnaces for the hatching of eggs: e02-16the Seeds of Silke silk=
worms, yea even henne hen eggs are sayd said to be hatched by the warmth of a Virgins
breasts: e02-17Art therefore and Nature doe do mutually helpe help, soe so as to officiate one for the
other: neverthelesse nevertheless nature is allways always the Mistresse Mistress, and Art the servant. e02-18But to say
the earth is the Nurce Nurse of the Philosophicall Philosophical babe, might create an objection to any
one, the earth being of all the elements most dry and voyd void of juice, to which siccity
as the proper quality appertains: e02-19but it may be answerd answered, that the earth elemented
is here understood, not the Element, which wee we tooke took notice enough of in the first
day of the Philosophicall Philosophical weeke week, and explained nature: e02-20This (earth) is the Nurce nurse
of Cælum, not in opening, washing or watering the babe, but coagulating, fix=
ing and colouring, and converting it into mere juice and blood: e02-21For nutri=
tion implyes implies augmentation in length, breadth, and depth, that is, extending
itselfe itself through all dimensions of the body, which being here, and performd performed
by earth alone to the Philosophicall Philosophical babe, the name of Nurce nurse is not
without reason to be ascribd ascribed to earth: e02-22but a thing contrary to the other
kinds of milke milk, which are converted and doe do not convert, happens in this
admirable terrestriall terrestrial juice, it by reason of its most efficacious virtue
much altering the nature of the thing nourished, even as the milke milk of
the wolfe wolf is beleiv'd believed to have disposed the body of Romulus into a mag=
nanimous nature, and propense to warre war. . . . . . . .

head.title: Atalanta Fugiens (Beinecke Ms. transcription) Facsimile Copy. Emblem

h3.span: Embleme Emblem 3. Of the Secrets of Nature.

h1.span: Goe Go to the woman washing cloaths clothes, and doe do you after the same manner.

div.div:
If you delight to dive in things abstruse,
Be vigilant, observe what may conduce:
Doe Do you not see, how women wash and boyle boil
Their cloaths clothes in waters hott hot, if they gett get soyle soil?
Pursue their steps, you cannot goe go astray,
For water washeth any filth away.

e03-01If some certaine certainany impurityes impurities happen to linnen linen cloaths clothes, whereby they are spot=
ted and blacke black, as with earthy recrements, they are washd washed away by the next
Element, namely water, and the cloaths clothes exposed to the aire air, that the moisture
together with the fæces feces may be drawne drawn out by the heat of the Sunne Sun, as by
fire, the fourth Element, if this be often done the cloaths clothes, which before were
foule foul and uncleane unclean, doe do become pure, and purgedfree from Spots: e03-02This is the art of
women, which they learned from Nature herselfe herself:e03-02 for wee we see, that if the bones of
animalls animals, which at first are blacke black and filthy, be exposed to the aire air, and often
washd washed with raine rain, and dryed dried agayne again by the heat of the Sunne Sun often coming upon
them, they will, as Isaacke Isaac notes, e03-03be reduced to perfect whitenesse whiteness: The same
allso also were observd observed in the Philosophicall Philosophical subject, whatsoever crudityes crudities and fæ=
ces feces appear, they are purged and taken away by their waters poured on, and the
body is brought to great clarity and perfection. e03-04For all Chymicall Chymical operations,
as Calcination, Sublimation, Solution, Distillation, Descension, Coagulation, Fixa=
tion, and the rest, are perfected by ablution alone: e03-05For hee he that washeth washes an
impure thing with water, performs the same thing, as is accomplished by soe so
many forms of operating: e03-06For, as the Philosophers Rosary sayth says, the linnen linen of
prince Duenech being defiled by sweat, must be washed by fire, and burned
by water: e03-07by which fire and water seem to have given one another mutuall mutual qua=
lityes qualities, or that the Philosophicall Philosophical fire is not of the same kind with coḿon common fire, and
the same must be supposd supposed of the water. e03-08As for Calx vive, and ignis Græcus wee we
know that they are kindled by water, and noe no wise extinguished, contrary to
the nature of other things that are subject to take fire: soe so they affirme affirm that
Camphore being kindled before burnes in water: e03-09and the Stone calld called Gagates (as
Ansell de Bood attests) being kindled is more easily extinguished by oyle oil
than by water: for Oyle Oil is notmixed with it, and suffocates the fired body:
e03-10water not being able to mix itselfe itself with fattnesse fatness, gives place to the body
being fired, unlesse unless it alltogether altogether cover and overwhelme overwhelm it: but that can=
not easily be done, because it is a stone, and swims upon the top of the
water, as all oyle oil: Soe So Naphta, Petroleum, and the like being kindled doe do
not much fear water. e03-11Some write of the Subterranean coals in the dominion
of Liege, that being kindled in the earth, they cannot be extinguished by
water, but onely only by throwing and heaping the dust of the earth upon them:
as

023Cor: e03-12Tacitus declares of the like kind of fire, which cannot be quenched
by water, but onely only by clubs, and garments taken of off from the body: e03-13there
is therefore a great diversity of 1fires, 8and 9noe no 10lesse less 11of 12liquors, 2both 3in 4exciting
5and 6in 7extinguishing, 13because milke milk, vinegar, Spirit of wine, Aqua fortis,
aqua Regia, and coḿon common water doe do differ much one from another, as to com=
parison with fire: e03-14nor this onely only, but allso also the matter itselfe itself doth does some=
times sustaine sustain fire, as those fine Byssinian cloaths clothes, formerly used and
esteemed by rich men, which were washd washed, or reduced to former cleanesse cleanness,
by fire, not by water, the fæces feces being burned away: e03-15Whatsoever some men
vainly talke talk of the haires hairs of the reptile Salamander, as if incombustible
16Discourse 3.
Elychnia or lamp wiecks lamp wicks may be made thereof, is not to be regarded: Some there be who of a
truth affirme affirm that in times past a texture was præpared prepared e03-16of Talke Talc, plumous Alum,
and such other matters, which was frequently purged by fire, but that the art
was lost and extinct with the artist (a woman of Antwerp) through envy, and that
the same temperament could not be found afterwards: Wee We doe do not here speake speak of
combustible matters: The Philosophicall e03-17Philosophical Subject must be considered according
to all these differences, if at any time it be præpared prepared: for fire, water, and matter
itselfe itself is here not coḿon common: for the Philosophers fire is water, and water fire:
e03-18their water doth does at once both wash and calcine, soe so allso also their fire: and the
cloaths clothes which are to be washd washed have the nature of the byssinean textures, or
præpared prepared Talke Talc, the temperament of which, and art of præparation preparation is allso also
not obvious to all men: e03-19To wash them, they make a Lixivium, or Lye, not
with the ashes, or Salt of Oaks, but metallicke metallic, which is more durable than
the other, nor with coḿon common water, but that, which hath has been congeled congealed into
Ice and Snow under the signe sign Aquary Aquarius, as that which is of thinner parts, than
standing waters of ditches or Marshes, and therefore can better penetrate into
the more internall internal parts of the blacke black and unclean Philosophicall Philsophical body, in
order to the washing and purging thereof. . . . . . .

head.title: Atalanta Fugiens (Beinecke Ms. transcription) Facsimile Copy. Emblem

h3.span: Embleme Emblem 4. Of the Secrets of Nature.

h1.span: Joyne Join the Brother with the Sister and give them a cup of love.

div.div:
To multiply the world with humane human race,
